SUMMARY:  On October 3, 2018, Ms. Evelyn Kahl, Counsel, and Ms. Beth Vaughan, Executive Director, of to California Community Choice Association (CalCCA), met David M. Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, in San Francisco. Ms. Kahl observed that the determination of “indifference” rests on the valuation of the utilities’ portfolios, since Public Utilities Code §366.2(g) requires that the Commission reduce the portfolio cost by “the value of any benefits that remain with bundled service customers.” Ms. Kahl explained that the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) does not achieve indifference in valuing the bundled utility portfolios and, instead, shifts costs to departing load customers. Ms. Kahl noted that the APD’s attempt to equate the products in the utilities’ portfolios with the benchmark proxies produces a material cost shift to departing load customers. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

[By Decisionmaker] SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, met in San Francisco with Barbara Hale, Assistant General Manager for Power, San Francisco Public Utilities Commission; Manuel Ramirez, Manager, Planning and Regulatory Compliance, San Francisco Public Utilities Commission; and Suzy Hong, Deputy City Attorney, San Francisco City Attorney’s Office, representing the City and County of San Francisco.

SUMMARY:  On October 4, 2018, Neal Reardon, Director of Regulatory Affairs at Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCP), met with James Ralph and Forest Kaser, advisors to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco.  Mr. Reardon noted that investor-owned utility shareholders should be subject to the risks and rewards of portfolio management decisions so that their incentives are aligned with those of ratepayers. Mr. Reardon emphasized the need to extract maximum value from existing contracts, and pointed to the California Community Choice Association’s voluntary buy-down and auction proposals as effective methods to achieve this.

SUMMARY:  On October 3, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, and Nicolas Chaset, Chief Executive Officer of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. Mr. Chaset expressed concern that no changes to the Proposed Decision (PD) or Alternate Proposed Decision (APD) had been issued to date in this proceeding. Mr. Chaset suggested that a hold be issued to delay the decision to give interested parties adequate time to respond, and that the Commission should consider allowing for a round of comments or another all-party meeting after any changes are released, given the significance of the issue and its impact on parties.

SUMMARY:  On October 1, 2018, Nora Sheriff, counsel, the California Large Energy Consumers Association (CLECA), spoke by phone with Rachel Peterson, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and on October 3, 2018, Ms. Sheriff met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman-Aceves, and Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, in two separate meetings in San Francisco, and spoke by phone with Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker. Ms. Sheriff stated that CLECA has bundled members, Direct Access members, and members who are now served by Community Choice Aggregators, as well as some members with onsite renewable generation to serve a portion of their load. Ms. Sheriff explained that with this membership, CLECA always tries to be as evenhanded as possible for purposes of how the different types of customers are treated. Ms. Sheriff told that CLECA strongly supports the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD), especially its treatment of legacy Utility Owned Generation costs.  Ms. Sheriff asked for the APD to be revised to explicitly reject the Joint Utilities’ proposal for a new, non-vintaged charge. Ms. Sheriff explained that substantial evidence in the proceeding weighs against adoption of the Joint Utilities’ proposal to change the power charge indifference adjustment allocator. Ms. Sheriff explained that if the Commission seeks consistency in allocation factors for bundled and departing customers, it should direct the filing of Rate Design Window applications on this narrow issue – which will give notice to other parties. With Mr. Gamson and Ms. Shmidt, Ms. Sheriff also noted CLECA’s recommendation that the APD be revised to allow for a de minimis valuation for unsold, excess resource adequacy and renewables portfolio standard resources that remain in the investor owned utilities’ portfolios, as opposed to a zero valuation.

Description: SUMMARY:  On September 6, 2018, Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer, Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, Dave Pine, President of the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors and Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE) Board Member, and Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, on behalf of PCE, the City and County of San Francisco (CCSF), and Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCPA), met with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Randolph, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Martha Guzman Aceves, in San Francisco. James Hendry, Regulatory and Legislative Affairs, Power Enterprise for the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission (operator of CleanPowerSF), and Neal Reardon, Director of Regulatory Affairs for SCPA, also participated on behalf of CCSF and SCPA, respectively. Mr. Hendry attended the meeting in person and Mr. Reardon attended by phone. PCE, CCSF, and SCPA representatives discussed the Proposed Decision of Administrative Law Judge Roscow (PD) and the August 14, 2018 Alternate Proposed Decision of Commissioner Peterman (APD). Ms. Pepper stated that a reasonable approach based on the record is to set the PCIA at the level contemplated by the PD or even maintain the PCIA at the current level until the second phase of the PCIA proceeding is completed. Mr. Waen discussed his experience working on PCIA issues over the course of his work with CCAs. Mr. Wiedman discussed support in the record for setting the benchmarks in a more reasonable fashion than either the APD or PD currently does and how the record supports the PD’s approach to the PCIA. Mr. Pine discussed the strong support for PCE within San Mateo County. Mr. Reardon discussed the impacts of the PCIA to SCPA’s residential customers while also noting that the rate tables PG&E provided on 8/31 contained errors which had not yet been addressed. Mr. Hendry commented that the PD/APD’s proposed value for capacity not only represents the low-range of values identified in the record of the proceeding but also represents the low range of the environmental attributes of the generation. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018 Jan Pepper, Chief Executive Officer, Joseph F. Wiedman, Director of Legislative and Regulatory Affairs, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst of Peninsula Clean Energy Authority (PCE), and Jeff Aalfs, Portola Valley Town Councilmember, met with Yuliya Shmidt, advisor to Cmmr. Rechtschaffen, and Forest Kaser, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. At the meeting with Forest Kaser also present was Mitchell Shapson, Staff Attorney with the Legal Division. Mr. Wiedman discussed support in the record for setting the benchmarks in a more reasonable fashion than either the APD or PD currently do and how the record supports the PD’s approach to the PCIA. Mr. Aalfs discussed PCE’s goals to drive decarbonization and support innovation in the energy sector and how those goals relate to the ongoing PCIA discussion. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

Description: SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, Barbara Hale, Assistant General Manager for Power, and Manuel Ramirez, Manager, Planning and Regulatory Compliance, for San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and John Reynolds, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Suzy Hong, Deputy City Attorney, San Francisco City Attorney’s Office, the City and County of San Francisco (San Francisco) was also present. Ms. Hale described San Francisco’s Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) program, CleanPowerSF, and the potential impacts on CleanPowerSF of the Proposed Decision (PD) and the Alternate Proposed Decision (APD). Ms. Hale discussed how San Francisco believes that the PD provides a reasonable transition to the longer-term solutions proposed for Phase 2 of this proceeding. Ms. Hale explained concerns with the APD and its potential negative impacts on CleanPowerSF’s program. Ms. Hale highlighted how these impacts would hinder San Francisco’s ability to meet the City’s and the state’s environmental goals. Ms. Hale and Mr. Ramirez discussed San Francisco’s positions on the PD’s and APD’s treatment of issues regarding pre-2002 legacy utility-owned generation (UOG), the 10-year limit on cost recovery for post-2002 non-RPS UOG resources, the value for the capacity benchmark in the PCIA calculation, and a PCIA rate cap and collar. Ms. Hale and Mr. Ramirez noted San Franciso’s support of the positions of the California Community Choice Association on these issues. With respect to legacy UOG and the 10-year limit on cost recovery for post-2002 resources, Ms. Hale emphasized the need to provide incentive to investor-owned utilities (IOUs) to prudently manage their portfolios and resources. Ms. Hale questioned why IOUs should be allowed to recover from customers the uneconomic operating costs of resources owned by the IOUs.

SUMMARY:  On September 5, 2018, Melissa Brandt, Senior Director of Public Affairs and Deputy General Counsel, Todd Edmister, Director of Regulatory Affairs and Deputy General Counsel and Nicolas Chaset, CEO, of East Bay Community Energy (EBCE), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Guzman Aceves, and with James Ralph and Forest Kaser, advisors to Cmmr. Picker, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. At the second meeting, also present was Mitchell Shapson of the Legal Division. The discussion concerned the Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA) and EBCE’s perspective on the Proposed Decision (PD) and Alternate Proposed Decision (APD).  EBCE representatives pointed out that the utility narrative that bundled customers are bearing a significant cost shift under the current PCIA methodology is flawed; PG&E’s 2019 ERRA filing (A.18-06-001) shows bundled customer rates substantially declining and the PCIA for departed load customers going up significantly. EBCE representatives explained that the APD differs from the PD in material ways that would have catastrophic consequences for CCAs, and where the PD balanced changes that would benefit utilities with those that benefit CCAs, the APD makes changes that solely benefit utilities. EBCE representatives noted that both the PD and the APD create a cost shift onto CCAs by making the wrong changes to the capacity benchmark price. Description: [JOINT] SUMMARY:  On April 30, 2018, Mary Lynch of Constellation NewEnergy and Scott Olson of Direct Energy, representatives from the Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), met with James Ralph, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, in San Francisco. Also present were Cynthia Clark of the University of California, George Waidelich of Albertsons and Chris Hendrix of Walmart representing Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), Mark Fulmer of MRW & Associates, consultant to AReM and DACC, and Dan Douglass, counsel to AReM and DACC, attended telephonically. Mr. Olson and Ms. Lynch explained that the allocation of Renewable Energy Credits and Resource Adequacy through the utilities’ GAM approach does not meet what other load-serving entities want and need. Mr. Fulmer described the elements of his testimony. Mr. Waidelich explained that DA customers desire energy cost stability and predictability and that the biggest impediment is the volatility and unpredictability of Power Charge Indifference Adjustment (PCIA). Mr. Waidelich recommended that the Commission should allow DA customers to pre-pay their PCIA obligation, based on a mutually acceptable forecast of that customer’s future PCIA obligation. Mr. Hendrix discussed the AReM/DACC proposal that the Commission should institute a cap on the PCIA. Mr. Fulmer clarified that there is already a “floor” in place and that adding a cap would create a “collar” where exposure of DA and bundled customers to volatility is more symmetric. Ms. Clark noted that DA customers in the current pre-2009 vintage tranche that have paid their stranded cost obligations should be permanently exempted from any PCIA or successor tariff.

SUMMARY:  On October 19, 2017, Geof Syphers, chief executive officer of Sonoma Clean Power Authority (SCPA), accepted an invitation to serve on an hour-long panel discussion at the CAISO Symposium in which Commissioner Guzman-Aceves was acting as the moderator and numerous stakeholders were present.  Syphers commented on allegations that Community Choice Aggregators are not paying their fair share of exit fees, and noted that the investors’ owned utilities have not been willing to undergo an audit or provide information to substantiate that claim. In addition, Syphers stated that by electing to hold onto no-longer needed energy and related products in a falling market, Pacific Gas and Electric Company created costs that both bundled and unbundled ratepayers are responsible for.
